resources.string:
The purpose of LearnBraille is to teach the basics of Braille in a fun and interactive way.
 The application is broken down into short lessons with interactive practice, followed by a lesson quiz.
 Users obtain achievements and points for completing lessons and quizes.
 There are also games the user can play to gain points and achievements.
Lessons allow the user to learn a small section of Braille at a time.\n Each lesson includes an interactive braille character that can be used to follow along and test characters.\n

Quizes are taken after you complete a lesson and allows the user to progress to new lessons.\n Quizes test the user by providing a braille character or english character, requesting the user to input the correct english/braille equivalent.\n
Games allow the user to accumulate achievements and points outside of working on lesson materials.\n

UEB Braille characters are composed of 6 dots arranged as two vertical rows of 3 dots each.
 The below represents a blank braille cell.
 The top left dot is numbered 1 increasing as you move down the left column.
 The top right dot is numbered 4 increasing as you move down the right column.
The first line braille characters all use the top 4 dots.\n Dots 3 and 6 are not used. These compose the first 10 characters a-j of the braille alphabet.\n
The second line braille characters add dot 3 to the first line characters and account for the letters k-t.\n
The third line braille characters add dot 6 to the second line characters and account for the letters u-z except w.\n
This quiz test the user on the ability to identify the braille layout.\n
